A4.text: Switzerland is bordered by Germany to the north, France to the west, Austria and Liechtenstein to the east, and Italy to the south.

A5.text: Switzerland contains two small enclaves: Büsingen belongs to Germany, while Campione d'Italia belongs to Italy.

A6.text: The tripoint where the border meets the Germany–Switzerland border and France–Germany border is in the river Rhine north of Basel.

A7.text: It then runs south of EuroAirport Basel Mulhouse Freiburg and then towards the southwest, separating the villages of Schönenbuch (Switzerland), Neuwiller (France), Leymen (France) and Rodersdorf (Switzerland).

A8.text: The border between the modern states of Germany and Switzerland extends to 362 kilometres (225 mi), mostly following Lake Constance and the High Rhine (Hochrhein).

A9.text: The tripoint is located in the Upper Rhine at 47°35′23″N 7°35′20″E.

A10.text: The border between the modern states of Germany and Switzerland extends to 362 kilometres (225 mi), mostly following Lake Constance and the High Rhine.

A11.text: The border between the modern states of Austria and Switzerland is divided into two parts, separated by the Principality of Liechtenstein, with a total length of 180 km (110 mi).

A12.text: The border between the modern states of Switzerland and Italy extends for 744 kilometres (462 mi).

A13.text: The border between the modern states of Switzerland and Italy extends for 744 kilometres (462 mi), from the French-Swiss-Italian tripoint at Mont Dolent in the west.

A14.text: The two countries share an open border, mostly on the Rhine, but also in the Rätikon range of the Alps, between the Fläscherberg and the Naafkopf.

A15.text: Liechtenstein is located between Austria to the east and north‑east and Switzerland to the north‑west, west and south.

A16.text: The Rhine, approximately 27 kilometres long, is the natural border between Liechtenstein and Switzerland and is important for Liechtenstein's water supply.
